body.p: By comparison to creating primary keys and subkeys, adding a new user ID to an existing key is much simpler. The method used to do this is key_add_uid and the only arguments it takes are for the key and the new uid.

p.codeblock:
import gpg
c = gpg.Context() c.home_dir = "~/.gnupg-dm"
dmfpr = "177B7C25DB99745EE2EE13ED026D2F19E99E63AA" key = c.get_key(dmfpr, secret=True) uid = "Danger Mouse <danger.mouse@secret.example.net>"
c.key_add_uid(key, uid)

body.p: Unsurprisingly the result of this is:

p.codeblock:
bash-4.4$ gpg --homedir ~/.gnupg-dm -K ~/.gnupg-dm/pubring.kbx ---------------------- sec rsa3072 2018-03-15 [SC] [expires: 2019-03-15] 177B7C25DB99745EE2EE13ED026D2F19E99E63AA uid [ultimate] Danger Mouse <danger.mouse@secret.example.net> uid [ultimate] Danger Mouse <dm@secret.example.net> ssb rsa3072 2018-03-15 [E] [expires: 2018-09-13]
bash-4.4$
